name: The Android IDE and Some Application Basics
why: Chris will be sharing some instructional material he put together about and android basics.

name: Managing API fragmentation in Android
description: Each version of Android incrementally fragments the Android APIs as new APIs are added and existing APIs are deprecated. To reach the broadest audience and include robust features your application will need to deal with this API fragmentation. If you are not careful API management  will lead to a complex code base and bugs. In this presentation you will learn how to use multi-project builds, reflection and Eclipse to enable your application to support multiple Android versions with minimal effort. Also learn how these techniques can be used to manage free and paid Android application.

name: Networking and Group Work Meetup
description: This month we are having a low key meetup. Come to network with other android developers or bring your current projects to show off or work on in a group setting. There will be pizza and drinks.

name: Bottle Rocket Open House
description:
Bottle Rocket will be hosting the monthly Dallas Android Developer meetup, providing an opportunity to see our offices, as well as hear from several of our employees about our development process.  We don't claim to have all the answers, but we have had our share of challenges, and so we want to help pass on what we've learned to other developers who might be experiencing the same issues.   It will be fairly informal, so attendees should come with any questions they have (about any part of the process) to ask our experts!

Come to the big Greenhill building at 14131 Midway Rd in Addison, park outside and take the elevators up to the 5th floor.  We'll notify security so there shouldn't be a problem getting in.  Up on the 5th floor, they'll be signs to the meeting area where we'll be giving our presentation.

Food will be available starting at 6:30, and we'll aim to start the presentation around 7:00.  The office will be open for informal tours before and after the presentation.

name: Vincent Button from AT&T about the AT&T Foundry
Android-to-Cloud Data Messaging and Remoting - Speaker may not make it.
description:
Unfortunately, It looks like our speeker may have to cancel!

You've got this great idea for an Android application and you want to utilize the scalable and cost effective resources that the Cloud offers. How do you get all of the pieces (Android, Cloud, database, etc) to work together without focusing all your efforts on integration? Afterall, the fun part is building your Android application!

 

This session will show you how to:

 

Use WebORB's developer productivity tools to bootstrap your Android development Configure native and non-native Android applications to invoke .NET and Java backend services using AMF remoting and RTMP; Deploy server-side applications in the Microsoft Azure and Amazon EC2 clouds; Load data from the server-side into a mobile application; Exchange messages between different client types Use various message queues for Publish-Subscribe messaging Push messages from the server to the client Mark Piller is the Founder of Midnight Coders and Chief Architect of WebORB integration server. Midnight Coders is an innovative and forward-thinking company specializing in integration solutions for web and mobile applications. Mark has over 17 years of software development experience. For the past eight years he has been specializing in building software infrastructure products designed to integrate a variety of web and mobile applications with .NET, Java, PHP and Cloud backends. Mark is very passionate about ease-of-use of software and prides himself in creating technologies that clearly demonstrate that quality.

Past presenting experience:

·         Adobe MAX 2010/2007

·         Adobe AIR Bus Tour 

·         Dallas Flex User group

·         Dallas TexFlex

·         Denver Flex User group

·         Silicon Valley Flex User group

·         Seattle Flex User Group

·         TechCrunch 2009

·         New York Flex User Group

·         WebManiacs

name: Mike Chenault will be giving a talk about Fragments
Mobile UX Question and Answer Panel
description:
Panelist Bios - More updates to come

Michael Griffith - Creative Director at Bottle Rocket - Michael has been designing all things digital for over 20 years.  Michael leads a team of Strategists, Information Architects, and Art Directors in designing relevant and engaging mobile user experiences. His background in visual design, advertising, and content development, blend together for a unique and holistic approach to UEX design. 

Nathan Weston - User Interface Design Lead at Approach IT - Nathan has been designing interfaces for a decade now. Nathan is currently designing the interfaces for a Cisco database reporting and analysis tool, but has spent most of the last few years deep in the nuts and bolts of interactive advertising design handling CRM, mobile, and voting systems as an art director. His love of animation and compulsive need to research have made his designs extremely successful across a broad array of media and devices.

Bill Townsley - Art Director at Bottle Rocket Apps - Bill has over 11 years of design experience. His primary focus has been centered around UI/UX design for many media types including mobile, web, and gaming. He has been designing mobile applications for the past 1 1/2 years and is currently working as Art Director on the Bottle Rocket Apps creative team creating apps for a variety of clients including BET, AARP, and A&E's The History Channel.

name: December Social Get Together: No Speaker
Writing Device Drivers for Android
description: Writing Device Drivers whereas once a fairly specialized skill has become less so over time. The explosion of smartphones and tablets running Android for example have mandated that device drivers require less time to write and integrate into the system. In this talk we present an overview on how to write a device driver for Android/Linux to support an optical touchpad for Gingerbread. We discuss the event handling mechanism that is part of the Android framework and how events are propagated to the user application from the Linux kernel.

name: Troubleshooting memory leaks in Android applications
description:
Learn some of the finer points of the Eclipse MAT and how to wield it to find and remove memory leaks in your applications. The presentation will consist of a high level overview of the tools followed by a real world demonstration with both leaking and correct code from problem detection to solution. We will also cover some best practices pieced together from experience and the web including how to properly use a WebView without leaking, how to use WeakReference, and what to do if a third party library leak is unavoidable.

 

Our presenter will be Adam Newman from Bottle Rocket

name: AT&T Mobile App Hackathon
description: Mobile App Hackathons is an event geared towards getting your app, business or idea venture to market! We will provide on-the-ground technical support, known as "senseis", from AT&T, Microsoft, Amazon, HTC and others to help you accelerate the execution of your ideas/business, rapidly kickstart a prototype mobile application and spin-off a successful venture.

name: BeMyApp Dallas - The 2012 Mobile App Olympics - Hackathon Competition
description:
BeMyApp WeekEnd is a three-day mobile app development competition.

Register Now →
You need to reserve your spot on Eventbrite. An RSVP here, on Meetup, does NOT count as a ticket. (But we'd love to have you RSVP here to get the word out about the competition.)

The event’s goal is to be a platform focused on building successful startups around the next generation mobile applications and to foster a global community of entrepreneurs.

App Challenge

& updates by BeMyApp

http://facebook.com/favicon.ico Facebook http://twitter.com/phoenix/favicon.ico Twitter http://ssl.gstatic.com/s2/oz/images/faviconr.ico Google+ BeMyapp.com On Friday evening, registered idea generators have one minute to pitch an app concept to a tech audience. We will be meeting at the Valtech location to hear a talk from Pieter Hintjens about how to use the ZeroMQ an open source library for high performance messaging. Afterward we will be getting together for an eat and hang out at Fuddruckers.

 

Fuddrucker's

4520 Frankford Rd, Dallas, TX

name: How to Get and Keep Good Ratings on the Android Market
Android - Sqlite, Content Providers, Loaders and Lists
description: Parsing some XML into a list? Most apps are. We'll look at using ContentProviders to store your data; Loaders to fetch it; and Lists to display it. We'll also take a quick look at asynchronously loading bitmaps in a list to make for buttery smooth scrolling. Come check it out.
how_to_find_us: The meeting will be held on the first floor. Enter through the main door and follow the signs to the left of the security desk. If you have any problems you can reach me at (979)324-7341.

name: Custom UI Controls
description: Android has a certain look to it, but what if you want your app to stand out from the crowd? One way of doing that is with custom UI controls.  Luke Wallace, Android Development Manager at Bottle Rocket, will be teaching several ways to build a custom looking app, from styling built-in controls to building something completely custom from the ground up.

name: Google IO Extended Day One
description:
Some of our leadership team will be recording the live events and we will be getting together from 6PM to 9PM to watch selected speakers and discuss them.

 

Day One Android Events we will be recording (Translated to our time not PST)

 13:45-14:45 What’snew in Android  Recording Jenn and Randalor Song?

 15:30-16:30 AndroidApps in Google Play  Jenn and Randalor Song?

name: Google IO Extended Day Two
description: Some of our leadership team will be recording the live events and we will be getting together from 6PM to 9PM to watch selected speakers and discuss them.

name: Android Form Validation & Feedback with Linden Darling
description: Summary: - A very shallow summary of the evolution of forms. - Form data validation and sanitisation. - Form validation feedback. - An often overlooked feedback solution. - Extension of that ^ solution.

name: Non-Native Android Development
description: Is your temper the only thing getting inflated by your XML layouts?  Or do you want to do custom controls with less than hundreds of lines of extra code? Stacy Devino & Stephen Wyile will explain resources available to rapidly build your Android application using familiar tools and easily convert it to --gasp-- other platforms!, all while using Eclipse as little as possible in the process.  We'll discuss several of these popular "non-native" development tools at a glance, then go deeper with examples of PhoneGap and jQuery Mobile, which we have used to win at multiple hackathons thus far in 2012. Bring your voodoo dolls and afterward, let's torture everything we love to hate about native Android development!

name: Embedded Webapps
description:
Matt Baxter and Nathan Smith will show you how to take the skills you've honed - building sites in HTML, CSS, and JavaScript - and apply them to building mobile apps. 
  

  We will cover building a basic web app, driven by a JSON API, and show how this can be embedded into a mobile app. Technologies discussed will include: Sass & Compass, PhoneGap, Handlebars.js, and Zepto.js (a mobile-centric JS library that is akin to jQuery).

name: Google Cloud Messaging and other Kewl Google APIS
description:
Google Cloud Messaging for Android (GCM) is a service that helps developers send data from servers to their Android applications on Android devices. Formerly C2DM, the new service is now free, unlimited, and easier to use. We'll look at using GCM in a REST based application and more. We'll also take a quick look at a few other Google APIs. Don't miss this one.

Presented by Don Archer - By day I'm an Android developer at Verizon. At night I'm working on bioengineering glow in the dark yogurt, but that isn't going too well so I usually just code for fun.

name: ARO webcast at the AT&T foundry
description:
ARO is a new tool from AT&T that gives you insight into how your application interacts with the device and the mobile network. Combining network traces with best practices, the tool provides feedback to optimize an application's performance — speeding up your performance while simultaneously using less battery!

Who Should Watch: 
Mobile app developers looking to optimize the performance of their mobile application. You will learn more about how wireless networks are different, and how simple design changes will optimize your app and minimize battery drain.

Join Us and Discover:

How connection latencies and state machines that exist in wireless networks are different than in traditional networks and how they can impact app performance. Simple best practices that allow your application to work with the wireless network, allowing a more optimal user experience. How to get the tool you need to design your app to use fewer radio resources, resulting in faster applications and less battery drain.
Presenter: 
Doug Sillars, PhD, AT&T Developer Program—Application Optimization
Doug Sillars is a member of the AT&T Developer Support team, specializing in Application Optimization and new device support. At AT&T Mobility, Doug has held several roles including leading the technical effort to launch hundreds of mobile web applications across a wide range of devices; leading the technical effort to launch video streaming applications on AT&T; writing many tech tips and support articles and providing support to thousands of developers through the AT&T Developer portal. Prior to AT&T Mobility, Doug deployed SMS, WAP and other applications across multiple carriers for AOL.

name: Lightening talks: Backendless Development, the Cloud as your Database, and more
description:
Do you have something android related you want to share, but don’t want to talk for a whole hour? Sign up for a 15 minute lightening talk!

In this format we hear a short discussion about a variety of topics, and then you have a chance to ask in depth questions to the speakers that interested you the most.

Speakers are encouraged to bring working source code to share with the group so that people who want a more in depth look into the topic have a jumping off point for their own development and something to serve as a backbone for more in depth the Q and A after the talks.

This month’s short topics will include

Modifying and Using Googles Open source barcode Scanning Developing for Android with BaaS (Backend-as-a-Service) platforms, using Backendless as an example. how you can use the cloud as your app database using Microsoft Azure Mobile Services. An overview of the new DevAppsDirect app. DevAppsDirect is an app for Android developers. It lets you experience Android libraries using a "Virtual Installer". The goal is to help developers make a discovery that will take their app to the next level. email the organizers to get add here.

There wont be an official leader or a speaker, more of an interactive event, but I will be happy to help out any newcomers who need help with their environments.

 

See you guys tomarrow.

name: Dallas Android Coding Challenge
description:
Dallas Android Developers is having its first ever coding challenge.

The challenge criteria itself will be announced at 6 p.m. at Bottle Rocket Apps on the day of the event. Everyone will write an app based on the same criteria. Apps must be turned in by 9:00 pm. The contest will be an individual exercise (no teams).

Judging will be arbitrary, hopefully fair, and weighting based on level of entrant expertise. Each contestant will be given two minutes to show their app and go over implemented features starting at the turn in deadline. Limited technical assistance will be available to help entrants past technical roadblocks.

A Galaxy Note 2 will be awarded to the winner. The prize was generously provided by Samsung. Samsung has some very exciting ways of communicate with their hardware. Go grab some APIs at developer.samsung.com (not part of the contest).

Direct any questions to Randall via meetup.com. Dallas Android organizers, as well as Samsung and Bottle Rocket employees are not eligible for the prize but may accept the challenge and show their work.

May the best implementation win.

name: Android Sensors
description:
During this talk Adam Stroud and Greg Milette, Authors of Professional Android Sensor Programming, will show you the code and techniques you need to handle common sensor-related issues.

Speaker Bios:

Adam Stroud is the lead developer for the Android version of RunKeeper. He is a self-proclaimed “phandroid” and is an active participant in the Android virtual community on StackOverflow and Android Google groups.

Greg Milette is a programmer, author, entrepreneur, and musician who loves writing practical Android apps, wiring Arduino hardware, and implementing great ideas. He is the founder of Gradison Technologies, Inc, contributor to StackOverflow, drummer, and father of two.

name: Android Programming Competition
description:
The Dallas Android Developers Group is hosting a coding competition in place of our regular meeting on June 13. Entrants should plan to arrive at the third floor in the Valtech building by 6:00. We are starting an hour earlier than our usual meeting time to allow 3 hours for coding. Details of the competition will be released at 6:00 and coding will stop at 9:00 for judging. (If you can't make it by 6:00, come anyway. Late starters will be allowed.)

This is a competition for developing native Android apps (written in Java or C++). No entries using jQuery Mobile, PhoneGap/Cordova, etc. will be accepted. Apps must be built into an APK by 9:00 sharp. This is an individual competition (no teams). Searching the Internet for answers and using code snippets for existing code is acceptable (within reason).

The Entrants will designate their level of proficiency based of the following guidelines:

Novice: has played with Android before, but hasn’t released any apps to any app store. Intermediate: some experience with Android, programmer by day, has released an app or two. Advanced: lots of exposure to Android, Android developer as full-time job, has released multiple app There will be 3 - 4 judges who will make the rounds after 9:00 and view each app as it is presented on the contestant’s phone or emulator. Contestants will need to show what achievements have been completed.

To be strongly considered for a top prize, a contestant must complete at least the basic achievement for his or her level, with the basic achievements being cumulative, i.e. intermediate contestants should complete the novice and intermediate basic achievements.

This is not a teaching event. Entrants should have the Eclipse Android IDE or Android Studio installed on their laptop and must have completed the development cycle for at least one app.

 

We will be providing a $50 prize for the overal winner and tortilla casserole for food.

name: Open Source Mobile Services with AeroGear
description:
A mobile application which doesn't use Internet services is becoming an increasing rarity.  Additionally, there are more pressures to make classic web based services into more flexible platforms which provide services to a multitude of devices.  The goal of this presentation is to survey a small list of mobile service types (RESTful APIs, cloud PUSH, offline support, and sync) and provide concrete examples of how to use AeroGear on Android to interact with them while still preserving a great user experience.

About the Speaker:

Summers is a Sr. Software Developer at Red Hat working on the AeroGear project.  He is also a member of the Atlanta Java User Group and acts as its web chair.  He got an undergraduate degree in Computer Science from Ga Tech in Atlanta.  He currently maintains a blog at blog.sagaoftherealms.net

name: Android Programming Competition
description:
Coding Challenge Overview

Prerequisites

Each participant should arrive with their laptop preconfigured with a complete Android development environment:

• Eclipse & ADT Plugin for Eclipse

• Android SDK(s)

• Ability to test your code on an emulator or physical device

It is best to have completed Android's "Hello World" & "Notepad" examples before arrival.

Experience Categories 

○ Novice
○ Intermediate (one app in the market or have completed a moderately complex app)
○ Advanced (pro or several apps in the market)

Rules of Engagement

Coding for the challenge must be completed during the challenge

Searching the Internet for answers is acceptable

Using code snippets from existing codebase is acceptable (within reason)

Timeline

• 10-15 minutes of stage setting and challenge unveiling

• 2 hours of coding

• 30mins - 1 hour of solution presentations, Q&A and open discussion

• Identify winner(s)

Definitely bring your laptop if you have one! It's not a requirement, but it is definitely encouraged. This is a time for you to show off any code snippets you want or to get help on any problem areas you have.

name: Strategies for Effective Use of Fragments
description:
Lets discuss fragments and how we use them: boiler plate implementations, best practices, fancy uses, gotchas, tricks and tricks, etc.

Bring your laptops. Share some code. Draw some diagrams. This should be a great event for developers of all skill ranges.

The meet and greet starts at 6:30. The meat and potatoes start at 7:00.

name: Android Security Basics
description:
This talk will cover the basics of android app security. 

It is targeted at an audience from android newcomer to the intermediate developer who has an app or two in the market. 

The main topics will be:

• An overview of the android security model

• Apk obfuscation and security

• Securely transmitting data  between apps and over the network

• Securely storing data

• Additional resources for further reading

name: Short Talks Session
description:
This month we are having short form presentations on various topics. Here is the lineup:

William Frances of Bottle Rocket
Topic: An introduction to AndroidAnnotations. See androidannotations.org for more information.
Bio: William J Francis began programming computers at age eleven. Specializing in embedded and mobile platforms, he has more than 20 years of professional software engineering under his belt, including a four year stint in the US Army's Military Intelligence Corps. Throughout his career William has published numerous technical articles, as well as the occasional short story.

Adam Newman of Bottle Rocket
Topic: Adam has compiled a short list of things you need to know to get going with Chromecast.
Bio: Adam Newman is an Android Architect at Bottler Rocket LLC and have been at Bottle Rocket since 2011. He's written a personal project for listening to/watching Podcasts with Chromecast support.

Kenneth Lewelling of DevAppsDirect.
Topic: Catch an early preview of a developer tool that merges the power of native android development with the speed and flexibility of mobile web development. Right now the tool is called NoDeploy.
Bio: Kenneth is the creator of DevAppsDirect, an Android app that allows developers to discover Android libraries by running their demos. Used by over 10,000 android developers.

Bottle Rocket is on the 9th floor of the building.
Food arrives by 6:30.
The talks begin at 7:00.

description:
*****PLEASE BE SURE TO SIGNUP ON THE FORMSTACK LINK TO SECURE YOUR SPOT. WE CAN'T GARENTEE SPOTS TO PEOPLE WHO SIGNUP IN MEETUP********

This month we are moving our normal meeting get together for Google I/O extended instead.

Visit the link below and sign up
https://www.formstack.com/forms/?1755683-87JruuhTSe﻿

Our plan is to view and discuss the sessions or recordings on the schedule below. 

Wednesday, June 25th
10:30am - 1pm - LIVE Stream of Google's Keynote
3pm - 7pm - LIVE Stream of Google's Sessions

Thursday, June 26th
3pm - 7pm - LIVE Stream of Google's Sessions
7pm - 8pm - Cocktails  

Join us for a social at 7pm on Thursday, June 26th! 

We will have pizza during the Keynote and snacks and drinks will be provided during the daily session viewing. 

We plan on having multiple viewing rooms available, so there will be some choice of sessions.

name: Google Cardboard Virtual Reality workshop. Free attendance. $17 take one home.
description:
Do you want to see what's up with the new google build your own virtual reality viewer?

In this session we will build and experiment with google cardboard.  Expect to do some work with exacto knives and bring your phone to see if this new google tool is any good.  :)

We will have a few kits available for people to try out, but if you want to take your own home you will need to register and pay $17. (cost of parts and payment processing). FYI we will be following the google plans, but these are not kits from google.

We will have to receive payment by July 5th  to order the correct number of components.  

You can pay using the meet up link or if you can hand Jennifer McGee $15 in person (before the 5th) ~$2 is the processing free for WePay.

If you missed the pre-pay deadline you can still come and build everything for the cardboard and I will be happy to share

name: Building a Compatible Android UI
description: You’ve heard the statistics. 500 devices, 1700 devices, 2800 devices?! How do you build something that will look good on a device you’ve never even heard of? Let’s clear a path through the jungle of hardware and take on the beast of Fragmentation. See how one of the top mobile development companies handles this on a regular basis, without compromising the experience. It’s not easy, but with a few guiding principles, you’ll be well on the way to happy developers and happy customers!

name: Battle of the Image Loaders
description:
*****NOTE****** SPEAKER WILL NOT START TILL 7:30 ******

but it can be hard to get into the building after 7:00PM. I will post a phone number which can be called if you need help getting in downstairs. 

This month we have Nelson Ramirez presenting "Battle of the Image Loaders" where you'll learn stuff you never knew about image handling in Android.

The doors will open at 6:30 and Nelson will start presenting around 7:30. Please be aware that it can be hard to get into the building after 7PM. I will have a phone number to call to get in posted downstairs just in case.

name: Virtual/Augmented Reality featuring the Moverio BT-200
description:
This month Nathan from Dialexa (dialexa.com) will be joining us to talk about augmented reality/virtual reality.  The meeting is outside of our normal Thursday's this month so expect to meet on Friday (if you didn't notice the date).

Nathan will be presenting about the Moverio BT-200 from a developer perspective.

The presentation opens the discussion for the emerging AR/VR landscape and the devices available today.

We will look at the hardware and capabilities of the BT-200, especially how it is unique.

Then he will go over getting the developer environment setup for the BT-200.

Next we will look at some 3rd party SDKs for augmented reality that will help developers start developing more complete solutions quicker.

Finally we will look at some of the areas and applications that others are developing to further inspire developers.

Prelaunch Labs will have some of the Moverio BT-200 devices available for demonstration.  The device supports Android 4.0 so most 4.0 compatible APK's should run on the device.

name: Let's Code Together
description:
Get a jump start on your new years resolution to hone your android skills.

Come out and work through a simple coding challenge. These are designed to be simple exercises that should we provide a modest challenge,  promote better design and produce functioning code. 

It isn't competition, but a chance to all get together and explore an area of android. 

Focus: Android Wear.

Please come with Android Studio installed as google highly suggests using it for Google Wear development.


Location:

We have a new location! We are not at the Aberdeen on the 8th floor. 

Parking:

Guests can park in the visitor spaces on the first level of the Aberdeen parking garage. Then you take the garage elevator to the main lobby. Take the north elevator the the 8th floor and we will be meeting right next to the door into BottleRocket.

Advanced Challenge Lost Phone App

Create an App that will

1) buzz when phone leaves bluetooth range

2) Cause phone to ring from watch

3) Lock phone if watch out of range

Want to see how someone else did it? 

check out AndroidWearFindMyPhone

name: A Peek at Job Scheduler with Mark Murphy of Commonsware
description:
A Peek at Job Scheduler

This month's meeting will start with a short webinar from 6:30-7:00 and then continue with a job scheduler coding lab till 9pm.

_________________________________________________________________

A Peek at Job Scheduler:

One of the additions to Android 5.0, courtesy of the Project Volta initiative, is JobScheduler. This is an enhanced version of AlarmManager, allowing you to apply additional criteria beyond time to indicate when work should be performed. On the other hand, it is also a bit more restrictive, requiring a special JobService subclass to handle the background work.

In this 30-minute webinar, we will review how you can use JobScheduler in your Android applications, to offer functionality at lower battery cost for the user.

____________________________________________________________________

About the Speaker

Mark Murphy is the founder of CommonsWare and the author of The Busy Coder’s Guide to Android Development. He is active in supporting the Android developer community, from answering questions on StackOverflow to publishing sample code and reusable components as open source.

name: Android (plus iOS and Windows) App Development in C# with Xamarin
description:
We know there are some C# developers in this area. Here's your chance to play with Android. This one is on a Tuesday due to timing with the speaker.

Presentation details:
Xamarin enables developers to create native iOS, Android, and Mac apps in C# and share code across all platforms while providing 100% API coverage on each platform. In this session we will go over all of the products on the Xamarin platform including the development tools and how they work under the hood to leverage the .NET framework in iOS, Android, and Mac apps. We will dive into creating Android apps in C# inside of Xamarin Studio & Visual Studio comparing how it would be done in Java and build our first Android app in C#. We will cover how to design user interfaces with Xamarin and how to add rich functionality with pre-built components. To finish it off we will cover how to share the code we wrote to reach over 2.6 Billion devices running other platforms such as iOS and Windows. Bio:
James Montemagno is a Developer Evangelist at Xamarin and Android Fanboy. He has been a .NET developer for over a decade working in a wide range of industries including game development, printer software, and web services. Previously, James was a professional mobile developer on the Xamarin platform for over 3 years, with several published apps on iOS, Android, and Windows. He can be found on Twitter @JamesMontemagno and blogs code regularly on his personal blog www.MotzCod.es

name: What Your Mother Didn't Teach You About Prototyping
description:
Hi everyone,

Just a couple quick notes about parking and getting to tonights meeting.

Our meeting are located on the 8th floor of the Aberdeen building at 14841 Dallas Parkway.

Please use visitors parking on the first floor of the north parking garage. The doors to the  parking garage elevators lock at 7:00pm.  If you find yourself locked out you can call my cell [masked] and I will arrange for you to get in.  Also be sure to use the north elevator to be from the 1st floor of the Aberdeen building to the 8th floor.  The doors are locked at the top of the south elevator. 

If you would like Wifi access please rsvp and update your meetup account to have both first and last name. If that doesn't work for you feel free to reach out to me and we can arrange something.

name: Post Google I/O Discussion
description: Lets get together and talk about Google I/O. We will also have a short QA session from some of the attendees about their I/O experience and highlights.

name: Google Fit lightning talk, Android Studio 1.3 Exercises
description:
This month Luke Wallace from Bottle Rocket will be giving a short (10-15 minute) talk on Google fit.

Also because the stable version of Android studio 1.3 was released on the July 30th, lets get to gather and try out some of the new features. 

We will be providing some exercises and examples so people can try out 

-How the Android Memory (HPROF) Viewer works in android studio

and a few more features

name: Android M Permissions
description:
The upcoming Android M release changes the way permissions are granted and handled in the system, with the goal of a more fluid experience and more refined user control. While this is a good thing, it also puts a larger burden on app developers creating new apps as well as authors of legacy apps. This presentation, from Larry Schiefer of HIQES, will take a look at the basics of permissions, the impact to the user and the impact to you, the developer.

Larry Schiefer is the CTO and co-founder of HIQES LLC, creators of mobile applications, mobile platforms and embedded system software. Larry is a recognized Google Developer Expert (GDE) for Android, an avid mobile/embedded software developer, has spoken several times at AnDevCon, and has provided face to face and recorded developer training on Android's internals, app development and security.

name: Big Android BBQ
description:
Ok you got us, The Big Android BBQ is not an really a Dallas Android Developers meetup, (so you can't RSVP here) but it is such a good opportunity that we had to list it.  

It has large google presence not to mention some other great speakers, and you can go without even getting on a plane. 

Caveat: It does cost money. $75 

*We the meetup organizers promise that this a true and unbiased recommendation and we did not receive compensation of any kind. Seriously, if you are into android  development and you are in Dallas this is a no brainer.

name: Dagger 2 for Android - An Introduction
description:
Randall Mitchell will give a presentation on Dagger 2, Android's latest best friend in the world of dependency injection.  He'll take you through the basics of creating modules and components, then show you how to drive them into Android UI.

Randall is a Senior Android Developer at Bottle Rocket Studios, where he has been developing Android applications for over three years.  He is also one of the founders and  organizers/co-organizers of the Dallas Android Developer Group.  He's been contributing to the group since it's inception in 2011.  He loves Java, which he first picked up in the Java 2 days.  He loves blending great architecture and great UI to create compelling user experiences.  He also love good wine, good beer, Naughty Dog Playstation games, and any good science fiction and fantasy series.

Food, beverages, and networking begins as 6:30.  Presentation starts at 7.

name: Network Performance : Design, Analyze, Implement
description:
Otherwise known as "Big Trouble in Little Networks" presented by Stacy Devino

We will start with analyzing your application, then move onto design structures and implementation of various techniques to improve network performance and usability. This will cover things like Data stream compression, Image Compression, Image architecture and Design, Rendering packages, and monitoring speed.

This will be a more in-depth and bigger expansion of the discussion I gave at the Big Android BBQ and will be more directly applicable to people who will be there getting started.

Speaker Bio:

Stacy is a recognized Intel Innovator, Six Sigma Blackbelt, and is the Women Techmakers Lead for Dallas/Ft. Worth. She specializes in high performance Android application and embedded coding as well as IoT product innovation. You can find her work in Android in the Play Store and documented on the front pages of Wired, Gizmodo, XDA-developers, Military Times, etc. Her hardware hacking and product invention status has shown up on HackaDay, LifeHacker, Dangerous Prototypes, Geek.com, Wired, Kickstarter, and even appearances on GeekBeatTV. Her secondary business, OpenBrite specializes in making and producing fully Open Source (OSHW and OSS) products made in the US. They also act as a product accelerator for crowd-funded and early-stage hardware companies from making of early prototypes through to full-scale production. You may have seen some of her products on Kickstarter and and Grand St.

name: Women TechMakers Event: International Women's Day-after Beer Tasting
description:
This is a cross-posted event from the DFW Women TechMakers event. Please get more details at their event here: http://www.meetup.com/Women-Techmakers-DFW/events/229321054/

It's coming up soon!

name: Going beyond AsyncTasks and Loaders with Ground Control
description:
Ground Control provides asynchronous queueing, coalescing, execution and short term caching of background operations.

Adam Newman is Bottle Rocket’s Android Architect and has been developing on Android for 6 years.

name: What's New in Android "N"
description:
It's that time of year again, for us to discuss the big new features of our favorite mobile platform! Come and listen to our GDG organizers discuss what they've read, and contribute to the conversation!

This presentation will be led by Luke Wallace, one of the GDG Dallas organizers, and Director of Android Engineering at Bottle Rocket.

Food, beverages, and networking begin at 6:30. Presentation starts at 7.

name: Google I/O Extended Viewing Party
description:
Google I/O is Google’s annual developer event held in Mountain View, CA. Our I/O Extended event in Las Colinas will include live streaming of the I/O keynote and subsequent sessions through Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Some sessions will include code examples and exercises! Bring your laptop!

https://events.google.com/io2016/extended

io16.png

name: Google I/O Live Hangout for Firebase!
description:
Google will be hosting a live hangout for Q&A around the latest version of Firebase, which has gotten a lot of updates this year. From Google:

----

Join us for a two-hour live streamed developer #AskFirebase Q&A from wherever you are. On May 26th at 3:00 PM PDT you will be able to ask James Tamplin, co-founder of #Firebase, and +Magnus Hyttsten, Firebase Developer Advocate, questions about Firebase LIVE! Make sure to start posting your questions today with#AskFirebaseLive. 

----

The live stream starts at 5PM Central time, but it will last two hours, so feel free to join whenever you can. Starting around 7, we will recap the event for those that come later, and brainstorm ways we might be able to use it, either as developers, or just as users!

We will also have a few attendees who went to I/O share what they learned, and give you an overview of what went on at the event.

description:
A series of Lightning talks about your favorite tools and libraries for development. Each talk should be 15 minutes long.

Some of the talks will be

-Espresso a quick intro Jing Chang

-An overview of LeakCanary by Jennifer McGee

-Retrofit by Stacy Devino

name: Intro to Polymer
description:
Polymer, Web Components, and the Future of Web Development

In this session we'll give you a comprehensive overview of Google's Polymer web component tools. Web components are the future of web development and Google's built a fantastic library of components to get you started.

Come by and check it out. We'll show you web components for fetching JSON data, user input, validation, and tons more powerful features. If you're new to Polymer, this meetup is for you. If you're a seasoned Polymerite, we'll try to show you a few tricks you may not know.

description:
Our friends at : DFW Sensor & IoT Technology Meetup will be hosting this event, and it is also posted on their meetup page.

“Code Walkthrough: Android Device Onboard Sensor Access”

Most contemporary Android devices have one or more sensors, such as motion, humidity, and light sensors. In this presentation, we will show and discuss sample code in Android Studio for the following steps:

1. Setting up an activity to display sensor values

2. Enumerating onboard sensors

3. Retrieving sensor values

4. Displaying & storing sensor values

name: [Partner Event] Workshop: Onboard Android Sensor Access
description:
Our friends over at DFW Sensor & IoT Technology Meetup are hosting an IoT workshop at the Makerspace.

Please RSVP here: http://www.meetup.com/DFW-Sensor-Technology/events/232386710/

More details:

Most contemporary Android devices have one or more sensors, such as motion, humidity, and light sensors. The July session is a presentation format. This session will be hands-on where you bring a laptop and Android device and step through the same. We will step through the following:

1. Setting up an activity to display sensor values

2. Enumerating onboard sensors

3. Retrieving sensor values

4. Displaying sensor values In order to have the best odds of making it through all of the steps, you should be familiar with classes/objects/properties and conditional statements.

You'll need a laptop, recent Android device, and the USB connector cable. You should install Android Studio and have installed the driver for your Android device, which you'll normally find by searching on "your phone model drivers" Presenters

Stacy Devino - Android Innovator at The Home Depot Leroy Levin - Mobile app developer John Lindsay - Novice Android developer Agenda

6:00 - 6:30 Check-In, Networking, Android Studio and driver install 6:30 - 8:00 Workshop 8:00 - 8:15 Q&A @dfwsensortech

name: Polymer Behaviors
description:
Polymer supports extending custom elements with shared code modules called behaviors. This talk will take you through creating behaviors to get the most mileage from your code! Polymer is all about reuse and modularity in web development. Come see how deep the rabbit hole goes.

We will have complimentary food and drinks available.

name: Android Multi-Window Basics
description:
** Doors Open & Pizza will be available starting at 6:30PM, Talk starts at 7 **

Android 7.0 Nougat introduced multi-window to the platform. Google says that it's easy, but what do you really need to know to get started? Brett McCormick from Bottle Rocket will be giving a presentation that covers all the basics, such as:

• Types of Multi-window

• Activity Lifecycle with Multi-windows

• UX Best Practices

• And lots of pro-tips!

Come and learn what you'll need to do to get multi-window working in YOUR app, you might be surprised just how easy it is!
how_to_find_us: Park in the underground parking garage, directly under the building.

name: Polymer Jumpstart: Build your first Polymer app
description:
If you're a web developer, this is your meetup. During this session, we'll get you started with Polymer development. There's no easier way to make your first Polymer module and open up the world of web components. We'll have staff on hand to help you set up your dev environment and walk you through building a starter polymer app. Bring your laptop!

6:30pm Meet and Greet with food

7:00pm Get started!

name: Android Push notifications
description:
Push notifications are a very important feature in current mobile Apps. This technology enables companies to communicate to their customer/client and let app users take advantage of their promotions.
I will go through the general overview of how push messages work and walk through a code implementation using one of the vendors.

Sai Gundumonu
Is a Sr. Software Engineer at Bottle Rocket, with 10 years of experience writing code and more than 6 years of experience in Android mobile app development. He has worked on a variety of android mobile applications like Sam's Club, Lowe's, P.F.Chang's, Food Network In The Kitchen, Fox News, and Coca-Cola Freestyle.

name: Hands-On With Machine Learning APIs
description:
Explore Google's machine-learning services, and stay after the presentation to solicit help on the examples or your own projects.

Need a kickstart to your next (or first) machine learning project? Lots of tasks are now made simple by APIs offered by various vendors including Microsoft, Google, HP, and Amazon.

This class will walk you through services offered by Google such as TensorFlow, the Mobile Vision API, and the Cloud Natural Language API. We will interact with these services live through the browser, see compelling demos, and you will learn how to make requests to them through your own application. Come prepared with an idea or something that's been stumping you, because after the presentation, we will have workshop time where we will be free to collaborate and ask questions of each other.

Before the class, it is recommended that you follow the instructions here so that you can follow along: https://github.com/mrcity/mlworkshop/

name: Constraint Layout
description:
Doors Open at 6:30 PM, presentation starts at 7 PM. The doors from the parking garage automatically lock at 7 PM, so you may be delayed waiting for security to open the doors if you arrive after 7 PM.

Google's new Constraint layout is rapidly approaching its 1.0 release with massive improvements in performance and the new beta3 released November 3. Come learn about this new layout before it becomes the default layout created by Android Studio. We will be covering the benefits of Constraint Layout, how to use Constraint Layout, and how it works under the covers.

Jennifer McGee has been a professional android developer since 2013, but has been involved with the Android community for the last five years and was one of the original founders of the Dallas Google Developers meet-up group. She has worked on applications for Opera, Hallmark, HGTV, and ADT, and others. She is currently an android developer at BottleRocket Studios.

name: Cross post for DFW Sensor: Google 'Android Things' Operating System Overview
description:
This is a cross post with DFW Sensor so please RSVP through this link not on meet-up. There is a $10 fee for the event to provide catering.

RSVP is required for the catering and headcount. Once again the link is:

https://events.vtools.ieee.org/meeting_registration/register/43331

Recently Google launched 'Android Things', an Android-based device OS for the Internet of Things. Google released a developer's preview of 'Android Things'. Even though nascent, it gives a glimpse of its possibilities. We'll present an overview of the operating system, including:

1. Some advantages and disadvantages 2. Currently supported hardware

3. Setting up a Raspberry Pi, as the "thing" 4. The development environment (hint: mostly Android Studio)

5. The programming framework There will be a demo of blinking an LED, detecting a button press, and logging a button press.

Agenda 11:30-11:45: Check-In

Networking 11:45-11:50 

Announcements 11:50-12:35 

Main Presentation, Q&A 12:35-12:50 

Closing Comments

Networking @dfwsensortech

description:
The TensorFlow Dev Summit is happening on February 15, but since it's during the day, we wanted to have a group watch event the following evening. We will not watch all of the sessions, but we will view the keynote, watch at least one other session (decided by popular vote), and have some discussion.

name: Android API Integration Tests with Mocked Endpoints
description:
Doors Open at 6:30 PM, presentation starts at 7 PM. The doors from the parking garage automatically lock at 7 PM, so you may be delayed waiting for security to open the doors if you arrive after 7 PM.

Android developers often fetch data from HTTP endpoints to display it on the device. One easy source of testing that will actually speed the pace of development from the beginning is end-to-end integration tests with those endpoints. However, in the end the tests can only be as stable as the environment they're testing. Chris Koeberle, Staff Android Engineer at Bottle Rocket, shall present a framework for creating these tests and semi-automatically creating an interceptor that will provide mocked responses to ensure the stability of the tests.

name: Android Fragments: A Retrospective and Best Practices
description:
Fragments were introduced in Android 3.0 (API level 11), which was 6 years ago! Since then, developers have gotten awfully creative with how to use them. In this talk, we’ll look back at 6 years of Fragments, discuss what went well, what could be improved, and some action items moving forward.

name: Spread your Wings with Spannables
description:
Spannables are THE key to perfectly scaled, dynamic, performant content. Stop using Html.toText() to do complex layouts that end up rendering fuzzy and slow in comparison. Create layered buttons without the overdraw or recalculation, support multiple font types and background images in a single line. Learn how to create complex Canvas drawings programmatically and multiple languages without destroying a layout.  Its perhaps one of the least covered APIs (even by Google) that is used by the Top Pros.

Stacy Devino is a recognized Intel Innovator, Women Techmakers Lead, GDG Organizer, Six Sigma Blackbelt, and long time member of the Dallas Makerspace. She specializes in high end android performance for millions of users. In her spare time, you can find her hacking vintage pinball and arcade machines, teaching classes on everything from beginning programming to 3D printing, mentoring, contributing to Open Source and a constant stream of personal inventions

name: Gradle and Android Studio
description:
Android Studio is smart and helpful in many ways. One of the most helpful things is related to how Android projects build.

When an Android application is created in Android Studio, the project comes with a set of automatically generated Gradle Project build files. We'll look into the details of these files to gain a better understanding of how they work including build types and product flavors. 

Also, we'll take a look at the Gradle Projects, Gradle Console and Build Variant view in Android Studio.

name: Remote Talk: Dagger 2
description:
Google's Dagger 2 library is a dependency injection library for Java and Android applications. In this talk, we'll cover what dependency injection is, why you'd want to use a library for it, and how to leverage dagger 2 in your android applications to simplify your application code and to enable some neat testing tricks (spoiler: stubbing and hermetic UI tests).

Presenter Bio:
Matt Dupree is a wannabe philosophy professor turned wannabe tech entrepreneur. He works at a Smart Lock startup in Orlando, Florida. He's passionate about testing and architecture and tries to speak and write on these subjects when he can.

name: API Development as an Art
description:
As developers, we are constantly interacting with APIs. Good ones can make feature iterations a breeze, and bad ones can waste hours of developer productivity. But we rarely stop to consider how they fit into our own work or how to be cognizant of potential design pitfalls. Using AutoDispose, an open source reactive tool for automatic stream disposal, as a case study, this talk will evaluate strategies and best practices for iteratively fine tuning real world APIs for better testing and the overall developer experience of your consumers.

Presenter Bio:
Zac Sweers is a mobile engineer at Uber with primary focus areas in Android, code gen, Kotlin, OSS, and avoiding sniffly APIs. He’s the creator of a few open source libraries like AutoDispose and Barber, and active contributor to several more.

name: Android Architecture Components
description:
Android architecture components are part of Android Jetpack. They are a collection of libraries that help you design robust, testable, and maintainable apps. Start with classes for managing your UI component lifecycle and handling data persistence.

* Manage your app's lifecycle with ease. New lifecycle-aware components help you manage your activity and fragment lifecycles. Survive configuration changes, avoid memory leaks and easily load data into your UI.
* Use LiveData to build data objects that notify views when the underlying database changes.
* ViewModel Stores UI-related data that isn't destroyed on app rotations.
* Room is an a SQLite object mapping library. Use it to Avoid boilerplate code and easily convert SQLite table data to Java objects. Room provides compile time checks of SQLite statements and can return RxJava, Flowable and LiveData observables.

Learn more here: https://developer.android.com/topic/libraries/architecture/

Bob Timm from Bottle Rocket will be presenting, with Q&A throughout.

*AutoML Vision
Accurately detecting cancer cells in slide images is an area of active
research. Most of the published research uses systems created for a
specific type of cancer. This presentation compares the results from
models developed using commercial software designed to be useful in a
variety of settings (Google's AutoML and Microsoft's Custom Vision) to
a recently published study that created a model to detect one type of
cancer.

Owen Remidez is a student at the Coppell High School Ninth Grade Campus. He spends his free time playing Minecraft.

*Firebase Services
The presentation will cover how to implement Firebase services into an existing app. This will cover Firebase Authentication, allowing users to sign into your app with their email address and a unique password. The presentation will also cover Firebase Firestore, a real-time database that can be integrated into your Android app, iOS app, or web app."

Matthew Timmons works at Code Authority as a software developer, specializing in Android. Matt has gained most of his Firebase experience while working on a personal project that is used to track the releases of upcoming movies, videogames, and concerts.

name: International Women's Day Mini-Conference! (with WWC DFW and Women Techmakers)
description:
Please register on the WWCode Meetup Here :
https://www.meetup.com/Women-Who-Code-Dallas/events/258855376/

It's time again for our annual International Women's Day event! We hope that you will join us for an evening of learning, and celebrating women in technology!

6:30-6:50 - Guest Sign-In
6:50 - 7:00 - A Word From USAA
7:00 - 7:25 - Women Who Code - A Year in Review
7:30 - 8:00 - The Main Role of Animations in User Interfaces, with Vanessa Alvarez
8:05 - 8:35 - Women, Programming, and the History of Computing, with Lucy McGuigan
8:35 - 9:00 - Final Raffle

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

OUR TALKS:

* The Main Role of Animations in User Interfaces, with Vanessa Alvarez*

Animations is a word mostly known in the tech industry as the nice-to-have decorations which in the majority of cases they turn into the low hanging fruit of a project. In this talk I will explore some examples of well implemented web animations with the purpose of demonstrating the benefits that animations bring to the users, the importance of animating responsibly and how to communicate animations across teams. My goal is to convey to the audience that animations are more than just a decorative they make web interfaces more usable.

Vanessa was born and raised in Colombia and moved to sunny Miami 12 years ago. Vanessa went to school at the Art Institute of Fort Lauderdale for graphic design. In 2016 she decided to follow a new passion for web development and moved to Dallas to attend DevMountain. She currently works at Alkami Technology.

* Women, Programming, and the History of Computing, with Lucy McGuigan*

This presentation will explore the history of women’s contributions to programming and computer science. Figures discussed will include notable contributors from “first programmer” Ada Lovelace and her revolutionary ideas about the applications of the Analytical Engine, to the women programmers of the 1940s (such as Grace Hopper, and the women programmers of ENIAC and UNIVAC), to programmers of the 1960s and 1970s (like Elizabeth "Jake" Feinler of ARPANET) who made critical contributions to the field. The talk will touch upon shifts in gender demographics within the field over time to re-examine the historical narrative of women in programming.

name: React Native vs. Flutter -The same app written for both platforms with Rap Payne
description:
We can talk about theoretical differences all day. But to really understand the characteristics and quirks of React Native and Flutter, you have to actually write some code. In this talk, we're going to dive into the exact same application -- A movie theater seat-reservation app -- written both in React Native and in Flutter and see where each framework shines and which is better. This apples-to-apples comparison will not only make it plain where developers would rather work but also where the true strengths and weaknesses lie for each framework.

About the Speaker:
Rap Payne has been focused on mobile development since he started Agile Gadgets, a mobile app development company in 2003. He is a consultant, trainer, and entrepreneur who has written apps, mentored developers, and taught software development classes for Fortune 500 companies like Boeing, Walmart, Coca-Cola, Wells Fargo, CVS, Chase, Lowe's, Nike, J.C. Penney, USAA, Walgreen's, and government agencies like the NSA, FBI, US Air Force, Navy, Army, NASA, Britain's GCHQ, and several Canadian provincial governments, to name a few.

name: Build with ALL of Google Cloud (GCP + G Suite)
description:
ABSTRACT/DESCRIPTION
Many of you are familiar with G Suite (formerly Google Apps) as Google's productivity suite comprised of Gmail, Google Drive, Calendar, Docs, Sheets, and Slides. You may also know something about GCP, the Google Cloud Platform, a suite of cloud products featuring virtual machines, data storage, networking, security, and machine learning APIs. While they appear to be disparate product groups, what you may NOT know is that behind each of the G Suite apps is a developer API, and that both GCP & G Suite can be used together to build powerful solutions. At the end of the day, it's not about the tech... it's about what problems you can solve with it. This session exposes developers to some of the more well-known APIs from both sides as well as highlights several novel solutions that have already been built. The goal is to provide inspiration and show developers the possibilities when they build with ALL of Google Cloud.

BIO
WESLEY CHUN (@wescpy) is the author of Prentice Hall's bestselling "Core Python" (corepython.com) series, co-author of "Python Web Development with Django" (withdjango.com), and has written for Linux Journal, CNET, and InformIT. In addition to being an engineer & Developer Advocate at Google focused on Google Cloud and one of the hosts of the G Suite Dev Show (goo.gl/JpBQ40), he runs CyberWeb (cyberwebconsulting.com), a consultancy specializing in Python training. Wesley has over 25 years of programming, teaching, and writing experience, and was one of the original Yahoo!Mail engineers. He holds degrees in CS, Math, and Music from the University of California, and is a Fellow of the Python Software Foundation.
